metadata.title: #HKPROTEST: Visualizing State Troll Tweets From China’s Disinformation Campaign | by Chua Chin Hon | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: #HKPROTEST: Visualizing State Troll Tweets From China’s Disinformation Campaign
metadata.description: In late August, as tension grew in Hong Kong following months of street protests against the government and Beijing, Twitter, Facebook and Google announced that they had discovered and dealt with…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: a quick exploratory dive last month
conspiracy theory that the US is the “black hand” behind the protests in Hong Kong

all_paragraphs: In late August, as tension grew in Hong Kong following months of street protests against the government and Beijing, Twitter, Facebook and Google announced that they had discovered and dealt with disinformation campaigns by Chinese state trolls on their platforms.

The campaigns were aimed at “the protest movement and their calls for political change”, Twitter said on August 19 as it released a trove of 3.6 million state troll tweets from what the company called “a coordinated state-backed operation”. Facebook and Google issued press statements but have yet to release datasets related to Beijing’s disinformation campaigns.

This is the second part of my examination of the troll tweets released by Twitter, following a quick exploratory dive last month. Here I’ll try to sift out the key words and rhetoric in the Chinese troll tweets, using a range of NLP and visualization tools.
First things first: Here’s the repo for the project with the latest notebooks. The CSV files are too huge to be uploaded on Github. Download them directly from Twitter instead.

This dataset has over 3.6 million rows and tweets in 59 languages. And it is extremely noisy — cluttered with sports and porn-related tweets, and a running war of words between the state trolls and fugitive Chinese billionaire Guo Wengui.

The state trolls accounts, now suspended, were also tweeting in multiple languages. Example, a troll which had set the account language setting to English could tweet in both English and Chinese, or more languages. Many of the accounts also had been dormant for a long time.
To make this project more manageable, I took the following steps:

Without aggressive filtering, it is hard to discern much from the dataset. This is true of both the English and Chinese tweets (as well as the retweets). Take for example the chart below, which shows the frequency distribution of the top 50 most common terms after filtering lightly for tweets involving Guo:

There’s hardly any word in the top 50 list that would hint at what this trove of tweets is about. The Chinese-language troll tweets are just as noisy, cluttered with spam content involving crime stories, US-China relations, and sunbathing, of all things:

In its press release, Twitter highlighted the activities of 2 accounts — Dream News(@ctcc507) and HK時政直擊(@HKpoliticalnew) — without explicitly saying why it chose to “showcase” these two out of the 890 unique userids in the dataset.

Digging through the dataset, it quickly became obvious that these two accounts were among a small handful of super active trolls that drove the Beijing’s rhetoric against the protest movement. These “lead trolls” tweeted actively in English and Chinese, and were frequently retweeted by less active accounts. It is unclear if @ctcc507 and @HKpoliticalnew controlled the other troll accounts directly.
A sample of the tweets by these two lead accounts:

It is no coincidence that the display names of these Chinese state troll accounts look like something a news outlet would adopt. This move to co-opt the identities of news outlets is straight out of the Russian 2016 playbook.

Some of the other accounts that were slightly more active, in Chinese, included: @charikamci, @KondratevFortu, @jdhdnchsdh, @shaunta58sh, @Resilceale, @qujianming1, @vezerullasav158, and @ardansuweb. But none approached @ctcc507 and @HKpoliticalnew’s level of influence in the troll network.
The content of the troll tweets is largely predictable, and runs the gamut from calling for support for the beleaguered Hong Kong police to condemning the protestors for violence.

But a particularly dominant thread among the “lead” state trolls is the conspiracy theory that the US is the “black hand” behind the protests in Hong Kong, which have drawn millions out on the streets.

I’ll go into some details about the Scattertext plot later, but it has a great feature where you can search for a key word within the corpus used for the chart and show which tweet/retweet the word appeared in. Here’s what turned up when you search for “ulterior”:
And if you search for “color revolution”, or 顏色革命:
I’ve uploaded the interactive Scattertext charts for anyone who wants to experiment with them without having to use or re-run the Jupyter notebooks.

The “lead” trolls appear to take a sharper, more paranoid tone when tweeting in Chinese. In the following two tweets, the account @HKpoliticalnew essentially accused the US Consulate in HK of working with “traitors in Hong Kong” to destabilize the city.
The troll also alleged, separately, that “many” Consulate staff were in fact agents with the Central Intelligence Agency, and that it had ordered for bloody clashes to take place:
A full content analysis is outside the scope of this analysis. But it will be interesting to see a full academic study of this Chinese disinformation campaign.
In the following sections, I’ll take a deeper look at the English and Chinese tweets, and the tools used to visualize the key terms.

Visualising unstructured text is hard. While frequency token charts and tree maps are useful in providing some quick insights into a messy body of text, they aren’t particularly exciting from a visual standpoint nor useful when you want to inspect how certain key words were used in the original text.

The tree map above, highlighting the 50 key English words used most often by the top 2 troll accounts, gives a very rough sense of the usage. But it is imprecise and not particularly useful when you want to directly pinpoint a word you are interested in.

Enter Scattertext, which describes itself as a “sexy, interactive” tool for “distinguishing terms in small-to-medium-sized corpora”. It has some quirks, such as the hard requirement for binary categories for the text you want to analyse. But otherwise it works great out of the box, including for Chinese text, and the detailed tutorials will enable you to try out a wide range of visualizations.
The interactive features are particularly useful in this case, allowing me to search for a key word in the chart and see which are the tweets and retweets that used that particular word or phrase.
I’ve uploaded the interactive files here so you don’t have to run this notebook in order to try out the Scattertext charts. Here’s how to interpret the chart:

ColourThe words in the chart are colored by their association. Those in blue are more associated with original tweets, while those in red are more associated with retweets. Each dot corresponds to a word or phrase mentioned.
Positioning: - Words nearer the top of the plot represent the most frequently used words in the “original” tweets.
- The further right a dot, the more that word or phrase was used in retweets (eg: legislative council).
- Words that appear frequently in both tweets and rewteets, like “police” and “china”, appear in the upper-right-hand corner.
- Words that aren’t often used in either tweets or retweets appear in the bottom-left-hand corner.

Key Areas:- Upper-left corner: These words appear frequently in the tweets but not the retweets. We still see a substantial amount of noise here, as evidenced by the appearance of words like “sterling” and “osullivan” near the very top.

- Lower-right corner: Likewise, words which appear frequently in retweets but not the tweets appear in the lower right corner. Here we see terms which indicate which are the popular accounts from which the trolls retweet — those owned by Chinese state media outlets.
You can filter the dataset anyway you wish and plot a custom Scattertext plot that suits your needs. In the chart below, I plotted for the tweets and retweets by @ctcc507 and @HKpoliticalnew:
Scattertext works great with Chinese text as well, as these two examples show:

The chart above plots a subset filtered for tweets containing the characters “香港”(Hong Kong). The chart below is a plot for tweets containing “顏色革命”(Color Revolution), “外國勢力”(Foreign Forces) and “美國”(United States):

The two notebooks for generating the Scattertext plots are here and here. I have a slightly more detailed explanation of the charts in the notebooks, for those who wish to dive a little further into the topic.

I also have a more detailed attempt at “de-layering” the Chinese troll tweets in this notebook. It is interesting, for instance, to see the differences in key words used in the tweets versus the retweets:

This dataset would clearly benefit from serious network analysis to find out how the troll accounts and key words are linked. I have no experience in this area and would be curious to see what experts in this area come up with.
I’m assuming that Twitter has some great internal tool for figuring out the network links between these troll accounts, in order to be able to shut such operations down at scale.

This brings us to a major question about how Twitter and the other social media giants discover such state disinformation campaigns on their platform. Thus far none of these tech companies have hinted at the methods or criteria with which they use to flush out the trolls. Are they too lenient, or too sweeping in their enforcement actions? We can only guess for now.
Finally, this sort of “desktop analysis” seems trivial given the events unfolding in Hong Kong. But hopefully it would add a little to our understanding of the complex issue when the dust settles.
If you spot any errors, ping me @
Building and reviewing AI products for newsrooms
